questions.prompt: The voltage-current relationship for a capacitor is:
questions.explanation: The capacitor current is proportional to the rate of change of voltage. If voltage is constant, no current flows — the capacitor is an open circuit at DC. This is the fundamental equation for capacitive circuits.

questions.prompt: At DC steady state, a capacitor behaves as:
questions.explanation: At DC, dv/dt = 0, so i = C·0 = 0. No current flows — the capacitor acts as an open circuit. This is how you find steady-state values: replace C with open circuit.

questions.prompt: At DC steady state, an inductor behaves as:
questions.explanation: At DC, di/dt = 0, so v = L·0 = 0. Zero voltage across it — the inductor acts as a short circuit (a wire). Replace L with short circuit for steady-state analysis.

questions.prompt: The energy stored in a capacitor with C = 10 μF and v = 5 V is:
questions.explanation: E = ½Cv² = ½ × 10×10⁻⁶ × 5² = ½ × 10⁻⁵ × 25 = 125 × 10⁻⁶ J = 125 μJ. Energy is proportional to the square of voltage.

questions.prompt: The 'memory' property of capacitors and inductors means:
options: Their state depends on the entire past current/voltage history
They remember the last circuit they were in
questions.correctAnswer: Their state depends on the entire past current/voltage history
questions.explanation: v(t) = v(t₀) + (1/C)∫i·dτ — the voltage depends on the integral of all past current. Unlike a resistor (v depends only on current NOW), capacitors and inductors have memory via integration.

questions.prompt: The dual of a capacitor is:
questions.explanation: Duality swaps v↔i, C↔L, series↔parallel. The capacitor equation i = C·dv/dt becomes v = L·di/dt (the inductor equation) under this swap. Every capacitor theorem has a dual inductor theorem.

questions.prompt: For a nonlinear capacitor, the small-signal capacitance C(v) is:
options: dq/dv at the operating point v
questions.correctAnswer: dq/dv at the operating point v
questions.explanation: C(v) ≜ dq̂(v)/dv is the slope of the q-v characteristic at operating point v. For linear capacitors this is constant; for nonlinear ones (like varactors), it varies with voltage.

questions.prompt: A capacitor with v(t) = 3cos(100t) V and C = 1 μF has current:
questions.explanation: i = C·dv/dt = 10⁻⁶ × d/dt[3cos(100t)] = 10⁻⁶ × (−300sin(100t)) = −300sin(100t) μA. Current leads voltage by 90° in a capacitor.

questions.prompt: The memristor relates which two circuit variables?
questions.explanation: The memristor (postulated by Chua in 1971) links flux Φ and charge q — the 'missing' relationship. Resistor: v↔i, Capacitor: q↔v, Inductor: Φ↔i, Memristor: Φ↔q. This completes the symmetry.

questions.prompt: If you connect a 5V DC source directly across an ideal capacitor (no resistance), the current is:
questions.explanation: The voltage would step from 0 to 5V instantaneously, so dv/dt → ∞ and i = C·dv/dt → ∞. This physical impossibility (in real circuits, wire resistance limits the current) leads to the impulse function δ(t) — studied in the next concept.
